metadata.name: BAI #161
metadata.description:
The first blueprint was found in 1947 on the northwestern shore of the Dead Sea.
It has been studied several times.
Numerous theories arose trying to explain its origin.
None of them was decided conclusively.

One year ago, a rare group of waves coming from space was intercepted on earth.
This happened during the 2021 summer.
It was unclear if they were born from natural events.
Dying stars, black holes... Humans tried to find patterns. Find a meaning for them.
None of the analyses made any sense.

Bai was a young physicist and Ph.D. student.
Her mother was a civil engineer working in finance.
Her father was an architect and a generative artist.
She had a personal interest in linguistics and algorithmic art, influenced by her father.
She was the one who managed to decrypt the information using her own algorithms.

Those frequencies were the gate to sets of technical drawings, matching precisely the physical blueprint found in 1947.

It's been a year since the waves were discovered.
No definite conclusions have been made yet regarding their origin or their meaning.
Nevertheless, the number of theories keeps increasing with every new blueprint decrypted.

The frequencies keep passing by the earth.
There is still so much investigation to be carried out.
So many questions to be answered.
Yet, the financial crisis is making the budget for investigation decrease rapidly.
The Institute of Space Sciences is running an initiative to self-fund this project.
Three hundred thirteen open spots can then seize those waves.
Encapsulating them as NFTs.


—--------------------

This project is an attempt to experiment with two main ideas arising from technical plans:

1. The inner beauty of architectural plans, city plans, industrial blueprints, and any other type of documents of that nature. A study of graphic elements like annotations, dashed lines, grids, etc. disposed of in different manners to create aesthetically appealing compositions.

2. How does the viewer analyze and interpret abstract compositions of technical plans? Triggering different thoughts and ideas: A Rorschach test with blueprints instead of ink blots.

—--------------------

All the minters at the first tear of the dutch auction will be able to claim A or B: A being one HD signed print of their blueprint or B their unique 1/1, on top of the NFT minted.

Those unique 1/1s will be pre-curated outputs from this algorithm. Some of the 1/1 parameters could be chosen by the minter: colors, main composition, shapes, density, name of the blueprint... so that the result will be a collaboration between the minter, Ismahelio, and the algorithm itself.

Minters at the second tier of the dutch auction can claim one unique 1/1. The difference with the first tier is that the minter won't be involved in the design process. The piece will be designed and curated by Ismahelio.

If there are any of these 1/1s to be claimed. They will be minted within an Objkt.com collection and airdropped to the minters.

—--------------------
Heavily dense compositions might not load on some mobile devices with insufficient memory.
The quality of the piece on phones and tablets has been decreased programmatically.
Visualize the piece in a powerful enough computer for the best experience.

Click 1: Activate
Click 2: increase speed
1: save 4000x4000 png
2: save 6000x6000 png
3: save 8000x8000 png

Original piece by Ismahelio.
August 2022. Madrid - Cadiz. Spain.
Made with p5.js

metadata.name: Vers #38
metadata.description:
Vers

A flexibility in regards to position.

V : Switch the top to the bottom or vice versa
A : Toggle reveal animation/title card
S : Save current resolution
1 -> 5 : Save low -> high resolution

metadata.name: BULLET #24
CPoSOP Composition #96
metadata.description:
This is the second in series of works where we pay homage to Ken Knowlton, scientist and computer graphic pioneer and artist who passed on June 16, 2022. Ken Knowlton developed the famous EXPLOR language, (Explicit 2-D Patterns, Local Operations, and Randomness) while at Bell Labs. He published a paper describing it in 1975 entitled: MINI-EXPLOR, A FORTRAN-Coded Version of the EXPLOR Language for Mini (and larger) Computers. (https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/988049.988052)

This work is a mark of progress. Christopher Scussel and I are working on modernizing MINI-EXPLOR. Chris is working on updating the engine from the original FORTRAN code of the 1970’s and its other limitations to usable JavaScript. In concert, I am analyzing and synthesizing the capabilities of the code and identifying an aesthetic. Together we continue to update EXPLOR and add new features.

CPoSOP Composition is an original derivative work of Contour Plot of Superimposed Octagonal Pyramids that was one of Knowlton’s original test examples. (Example 3)

The original EXPLOR picture frame was limited to a fixed array of 140 x 140 “characters.” Chris has rewritten the code to make the picture space variable. In this piece I increased the image space to a resolution 250 x 250  picture cells. Each picture cell is a 3x3 pixel block. 

The EXPLOR functions are designed to interact with the current contents of each cell in the picture array. Every EXPLOR function has a rules parameter. In this test I’ve added a background. Thus when I draw my modified CPoSOP widget over the background it interacts with the color contents of a background cell or, the color of the cell based on a previously drawn widget.

I’ve modified the original CPoSOP code and replaced constants with random variables. (made it a Spatial Force). I create a regular grid (Form of Spatial Organization) of a random size and draw the CPoSOP widget 85% of the time in one of the grid elements positions. The grid provides a structure to the image and the CPoSOP widget provides visual interest. The interaction of the widgets with the background and each other are amazing. 

In keeping true to an EXPLOR vibe we use 4 color palettes. We let the computer randomly pick from three predefined palettes: Black and white. Four colors randomly chosen from set of 8 “Bauhaus” colors. And, four truly random colors.

We continue to honor the passing of Ken Knowlton with this NFT series. Here is an opportunity to collect an example image from the famous program he authored now updated by Scussel and Kolomyjec. A true piece of Computer Graphic Art history with a modern twist.

Dr. Bill Generative Art OG @ drbillkolomyjec.com

metadata.name: Shattered Obelisks #19
metadata.description:
Shattered Obelisks began as a work that is dedicated to my habit of mindlessly drawing on paper when I am stressed, depressed or immersed in difficult thoughts.

Like a patient undergoing psychotherapy and piecing together the causes of unconscious fears and anxieties, I and my artwork have assembled ourselves into something shaped, found order in the chaos and separated it from the external noise.

It took 3 months of continuous, obsessive work. I have developed a huge library, designed for hand-like drawing. The functionality of this library is four times larger than what is shown in this drop.

I plan to put this library out into the public domain when I deem it complete, and hope that it will help someone express themselves through the creative process as much as it helped for me.

In case you've encountered a problem with inverted colours, try changing browser or disabling extensions. This problem only occurred once during testing on a massive amount of devices and was resolved by disabling extensions.

IMPORTANT NOTES BLOCK:

NOTE 1: This artwork should be viewed at a browser scale of 100%. Reducing the scale will increase the amount of detail, but may unpredictably affect the preservation of the location of secondary objects.

NOTE 2: This work can be printed on a plotter. Click S for saving it in .SVG.
Detailed instructions and answers to possible questions can be found in the console output of the code.

NOTE 3: This drop is the first one from the series of 3. It will be used as AL ticket in next drops of this series.

@abakshonokoleg
01.08.2022
Tech: P5.JS
License: CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

metadata.name: kylt #4
metadata.description:
Dissolving, dancing, decaying structures.

Using tinycolor2 and p5-noise.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: [glitchscape] #111
metadata.description:
this glitchy landscape is a place for you to get lost in as you wander keep your hands in your pockets keep your soul close don't stare at the sun it is oh so hungry.  

enjoy the evening sky.

---

this piece progressively renders until the final result is in place. please be patient as it chunks along depositing pixels to the screen.

palettes via chromotome.

---

press 's' to save high-res (3000x3000) image at any step of the way.

metadata.name: Sand Shapes #83
metadata.description:
An experiment in line texture by Nate Donato, this piece features lines composed of a sand-like particle texture.  Bounds around line generation properties were set loosely, resulting in many possible line characters with unique weights, wobbles, and more.  Lines are generated in individual layered segments one by one, resulting in a pleasing animation of gradual composition as they compose one of twelve possible shapes, in one of eight possible color schemes.  

Each "line" is made up of thousands of points, and so rendering the live view of this piece may be computer intensive.  As an added bonus a small amount of proprietary line data is emitted to the development console, allowing the minted collection to serve as a palette of potential line qualities for the artist to use in future works.  Any owners of pieces used in this way by the artist on future projects will be granted a share of said future project's royalties.

In active live view, press [1] to view medium res, [2] to view high res, and [0] to return to original viewport width view.

Written in vanilla JavaScript without the use of external libraries.

metadata.name: Illusion City #121
metadata.description:
Illusion City reflects the variety of Istanbul by its different and divergent zones, day and night, humid summers and ice cold winters, colorful neighborhoods and giant plazas, its never ending human and vehicle traffic.

This series is an expression of how we experience this city, kind of like a love and hate relationship. The city that is a cradle of civilizations now has become a concrete jungle. Our beautiful city and its citizens are now trying to find their own balance in this state of chaos.

We wanted to express these complex emotions with a long-form generative artwork since it is the most suitable medium to explore every possible combination of emotions we have about our city. 

Best experienced in full screen.

Probabilities;

- 3 pre-made color palettes, 1 generative color palette

- 3 blend modes

- 3 topping placements

- 8 different particle angle compositions

- Several grid sizes and edges

- An intentionally kept in glitch (rare)

In live mode, press ‘s’ to save as .png (2000 x 2666 px )

It can take up to a minute to render or longer in low-performance computers. Enjoy the process!

Made with p5.js

Ilgın İçözü, July 2022
@distcollective

objkt.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading #211

metadata.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading #211
metadata.description:
“Where in the world will words go, 
after us? How will they be arranged, 
and what will they sound like
when they arrive at their destination?
What will they be doing?
What will the world be doing?
Will the words be quiet or loud?
Will they be full of themselves,
or full of longing,
or full of longing’s opposite?”
 
An ars poetica on the future of literature and humanity. 
 
This project is a one-time generative poetry performance of a transhuman text by Sasha Stiles and her AI alter ego, Technelegy – read and unread by an algorithm authored by Nathaniel Stern. Every hash transforms one of 353 lines of AI-written poetry from legible letters into wordless language, generating a unique textblock from millions of possible combinations; each algorithmic translation unwrites itself, forever. Press "s" to overlay and toggle the original line of verse, and watch its shapes and meanings degenerate – or evolve – into an infinite visual poem.
 
All minters will receive an airdropped broadside (mp4) of the entire original poem after the performance is complete. A 1/1 media-rich audiovisual version of THE WORD AFTER US will also be made available.

 
Poetic traits:
- 353 possible lines of generative poetry produced by a GPT-3 language model fine-tuned on Stiles’ and Stern’s writing and research.
- 28 possible color palette combinations selected from Stern’s performative scanner art, with rare palettes including RGB, Hacker, Charcoal, and Chalkboard (black background).
- 6 possible fonts, including the premiere of Stern and Stiles’ custom AI font, NNFT (Neural Network Font Type), developed for their ongoing collaboration, “Mother Computer.”
- millions of layout and layering possibilities, including a rare “spiral” effect.
- billions of animation attribute combinations, which carry on forever.

attributes.name: Line
attributes.value: 347: There is no such thing as silence.

issuer.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading

metadata.name: Kinetic Bug #239
metadata.description:
Best viewed on a decent GPU,  because physics simulations are performance intensive. Otherwise you might encounter a bug...

In a world of digital data, a new life is born. We are not alone...
Explore how kinetic bugs make their way through the world. What will their destiny be?
It's curious that we can sympathize to a predefined creature living it's predestined life in the digital world. Coding in the computer abyss reveals interesting worlds.

Keyboard
[ space ] - jump
[ click ] - increase velocity briefly
[ r ] - restart simulation
[ s ] - save image
[ f ] - full screen

Mobile
[ two finger tap ] - jump
[ tap ] - increase velocity briefly

Created with Three.js + rapier.js
Copyright (c) July 2022 Shaderism

metadata.name: Malaphors #28
metadata.description:
Malaphor: Noun: An error in which two similar figures of speech are merged, producing an often nonsensical result.
Life is full of people giving advice and although we should always listen, we should take care to only follow good advice. 
What I love (and hate!) about proverbs is that they are nearly always used just after something bad has happened and are therefore often of little or no help at the time!

Each work features 5 Malaphors (mixed up proverbs) each in a color from one of 15 palettes.
There are 5 background colors: 
Black       - 80% chance 
Dark Red    - 5% chance 
Dark Green  - 5% chance
Dark Blue   - 5% chance
Dark Gray   - 5% chance

Additional variety is possible for amount of text and fluctuation amount.

Key strokes are: 

"S" - Save the image
"1" or "Spacebar" - Make the animation start if not already looping
"2" - Move the animation on a frame
"3" - Stop the animation
"4" - Randomise the text colors (must be looping or can press "2" to move to next frame"

Made by @p1x3lboy in p5.js 
August 2022

attributes.name: Text 1
attributes.value: A bird in the hand is worth two in the reward

attributes.name: Text 2
attributes.value: A bird in the hand is worth two in the fall

attributes.name: Text 3
attributes.value: Feed a cold and starve a fool

attributes.value: Don't leave your manners on the milk

attributes.name: Text 2

metadata.name: Clutter #6
metadata.description:
People have lots of useless stuff, some more than others, some less. Not only do they spend money buying things they don't need, but some of them require obligatory extra costs and care for proper upkeep. Let's say you buy a fancy car. You constantly make sure it doesn't get scratched, you wash it regularly, you say "careful about the seats" and you never allow someone to eat in it, since vacuuming is hardly something you like doing. Overall, it's just a burden.

Having something forces you to change your behavior. That's not necessarily bad, but it is a fact.
Everything you own, ends up owning you.

metadata.name: AngrySquares.gif #18
metadata.description:
An experiment in GIF serialization on fxhash by Nate Donato, this collection features a generative animation that can be automatically saved as a high quality gif.  Playing with block color and simple motion, each iteration features a rapid animation of basic shapes fluctuating under various different constraints.  The combined character of the full animation appears as an "angry" mass with pent up body motion and sharp color contrasting edges.  

Outputs can be programmatically saved to a high quality gif download, which can be used as a unique animated profile picture (*for any service that allows animated gif images)

Featuring:
x10 different possible color schemes (4 with near-infinite variations!)
x4 different possible generative weight classes (each with significant variation)
x3 different accent coloring styles (two with significant variation)
x7 different generalized anger levels (affecting animation speeds)
x6 possible special extra accent detail styles
x5 different base shape constructions
x1 'base' generative algorithm *

= 25,200 possible base feature combinations!!  Some traits and combinations are more likely to appear than others...

* Not included in calculations: a near infinite variety of shape positions, sizes, and placements, and a wide spectrum of possible animation lengths!


--


Keyboard controls:

Press [1] to view at native resolution
Press [2] to view at high resolution
Press [0] to scale to default screen width

Press [S] to save a high quality gif!* (May take a couple seconds to render)

*Tested in Google Chrome browser only!  
Should work in others but please use the latest version of Chrome if encountering any issue.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #169
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. “The Bugged Tree”’s code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren’t under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there’s a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: CPoSOP Composition #71
metadata.description:
This is the second in series of works where we pay homage to Ken Knowlton, scientist and computer graphic pioneer and artist who passed on June 16, 2022. Ken Knowlton developed the famous EXPLOR language, (Explicit 2-D Patterns, Local Operations, and Randomness) while at Bell Labs. He published a paper describing it in 1975 entitled: MINI-EXPLOR, A FORTRAN-Coded Version of the EXPLOR Language for Mini (and larger) Computers. (https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/988049.988052)

This work is a mark of progress. Christopher Scussel and I are working on modernizing MINI-EXPLOR. Chris is working on updating the engine from the original FORTRAN code of the 1970’s and its other limitations to usable JavaScript. In concert, I am analyzing and synthesizing the capabilities of the code and identifying an aesthetic. Together we continue to update EXPLOR and add new features.

CPoSOP Composition is an original derivative work of Contour Plot of Superimposed Octagonal Pyramids that was one of Knowlton’s original test examples. (Example 3)

The original EXPLOR picture frame was limited to a fixed array of 140 x 140 “characters.” Chris has rewritten the code to make the picture space variable. In this piece I increased the image space to a resolution 250 x 250  picture cells. Each picture cell is a 3x3 pixel block. 

The EXPLOR functions are designed to interact with the current contents of each cell in the picture array. Every EXPLOR function has a rules parameter. In this test I’ve added a background. Thus when I draw my modified CPoSOP widget over the background it interacts with the color contents of a background cell or, the color of the cell based on a previously drawn widget.

I’ve modified the original CPoSOP code and replaced constants with random variables. (made it a Spatial Force). I create a regular grid (Form of Spatial Organization) of a random size and draw the CPoSOP widget 85% of the time in one of the grid elements positions. The grid provides a structure to the image and the CPoSOP widget provides visual interest. The interaction of the widgets with the background and each other are amazing. 

In keeping true to an EXPLOR vibe we use 4 color palettes. We let the computer randomly pick from three predefined palettes: Black and white. Four colors randomly chosen from set of 8 “Bauhaus” colors. And, four truly random colors.

We continue to honor the passing of Ken Knowlton with this NFT series. Here is an opportunity to collect an example image from the famous program he authored now updated by Scussel and Kolomyjec. A true piece of Computer Graphic Art history with a modern twist.

Dr. Bill Generative Art OG @ drbillkolomyjec.com
